'''Market populism''' is a term coined by [[Thomas Frank]] for the concept that the [[free market]] is more [[democratic]] than any [[democracy]]. Frank himself does not believe this premise and sets forth arguments against it in his book ''[[One Market Under God]]''. The concept received major widespread prominence in the 1990s when it was used to justify the [[New Economy]], which consisted of a long [[Market trend| bullish trend]], and support for the free market.<ref name=Frank>{{cite web|title=The Rise of Market Populism|url=http://www.thenation.com/article/rise-market-populism|publisher=The Nation.com|accessdate=18 April 2012|author=Thomas Frank|date=October, 12 2000}}</ref>
==History== The concept's origins stretch back at least as far as 1933, when political scientist [[Harold Lasswell]] wrote:
{{Quote|The propagandaist outlook in fact combines respect for individuality with indifference to formal democracy. The respect for individuality arises from the dependence of large scale operations upon the support of the mass and upon experience with the variability of human preferences. The newspaper, the cigarette, the tooth paste, all depend upon a daily mass referendum. The possibility always looms that a new combination of appeals will supersede the old and push old tracts of fixed and specialized capital out of use.{{cn|date=July 2012}}}}
==1990's America== The concept of market populism became especially popular during the American [[New Economy]], which began in the 1990's. Academics, executives, democrats and republicans all shared the idea that markets were a popular system. In other words, because they were considered to be efficient at allocating resources, therefore the inefficiencies arising from poor legislation or unethical practices would be rooted out.<ref name=Frank />
